material.mattext: The Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) primarily uses which switching technology?
In the context of telecommunication signals, which statement is true?
Analog signals are discrete and represented by binary code.
Digital signals are continuous and vary smoothly over time.
Analog signals are continuous and can represent a wide range of values.
Digital signals are less susceptible to noise and interference than analog signals.
Which network type covers the largest geographical area?
The Internet primarily uses which protocol suite for data communication?
Which generation of mobile communication systems introduced digital signals for mobile phones?
Which technology enables the delivery of communication services like voice, messaging, and video conferencing over the internet?
Which historical telecommunication technology used Morse code transmitted over wires?
What is the primary advantage of using optical fibers for data transmission?
Lower cost compared to copper wires
What is the primary function of a transmitter in a telecommunication system?
To convert information into a transmittable signal
To route signals to their destination
What is the key advantage of 5G compared to previous generations of mobile communication? Multi-User Detection and Antenna Array Techniques
Which MUD technique sequentially detects and cancels stronger signals to improve the detection of weaker signals?
Beamforming is a signal processing technique used in antenna arrays to:
Reduce the size and weight of antennas
Eliminate the need for channel estimation
Smart antennas are characterized by their ability to:
Operate on multiple frequency bands simultaneously
Adapt their radiation patterns based on the environment
Transmit and receive signals at the same time
Increase their physical size to improve performance
Which MIMO concept involves transmitting multiple data streams simultaneously over the same frequency channel?
MIMO systems achieve diversity gain by:
What is the near-far problem in CDMA systems?
Signals from users close to the base station are weaker than those from farther users
Signals from users close to the base station overpower those from farther users
All users experience the same signal strength regardless of their distance from the base station
The base station cannot differentiate between users based on their distance
The Maximum Likelihood Detector (MLD) is considered an optimal MUD technique because it:
Searches for the most likely combination of transmitted signals
Is immune to channel estimation errors
Which statement about MIMO systems is FALSE?
MIMO systems can increase data rates through spatial multiplexing
MIMO systems can improve signal quality through diversity gain
MIMO systems can only be used in the downlink direction
MIMO systems require multiple antennas at both the transmitter and receiver
The primary objective of Multi-User Detection (MUD) is to:
Increase the transmission power of individual users.
Reduce the complexity of wireless communication systems
Separate and detect signals from multiple users simultaneously.
Allocate dedicated frequency bands to each user.
Which type of antenna array is best suited for 360-degree coverage? MIMO, High-Speed Packet Access, and Long-Term Evolution
Which technology utilizes Coordinated Multipoint (CoMP) to enhance signal quality?
What is the peak downlink data rate supported by HSPA+?
Which component in the LTE architecture is responsible for managing mobility and session states?
What modulation technique is used in the uplink of LTE to reduce the peak-to-average power ratio?
Which is the odd one out?
All these are key features of HSDPA except?
Which wireless technology standard extensively utilizes MIMO to enhance data rates and spectral efficiency?
What is the primary advantage of using 64-QAM modulation in HSPA+?
In the context of MIMO, what does SISO stand for?
Which MIMO configuration uses multiple transmit antennas and one receive antenna? Radio Resource Management and Packet Scheduling
Which of the following is NOT a key function of RRM?
The process of determining whether a new call or data session can be accepted based on available resources and QoS requirements is called:
In which RRM approach does a single entity manage radio resources for the entire network?
The primary goal of packet scheduling is to:
Reduce the number of packets in the network
Increase the complexity of data transmission
The transition of a user's connection from one cell to another as they move through the network is managed by:
Which Wi-Fi technology differentiates traffic into different access categories with varying priorities?
Which of the following is NOT a challenge in packet scheduling?
The primary goal of Radio Resource Management (RRM) is to:
Minimize the number of users in a network
Optimize the use of available spectrum and improve network performance
Increase the complexity of wireless communication systems
Allocate dedicated frequency bands to each user
Which RRM strategy allocates resources in real-time based on current network conditions and user requirements?
Which of the following is an example of RRM in LTE? Multimedia: Image and Video Representation and Transmission
The fundamental unit of a digital image, representing a single point with color and intensity, is called a:
The process of reducing the size of an image file by removing redundancy and irrelevance is known as:
Which of the following image compression techniques is lossless, preserving all original image data?
Which protocol is specifically designed for controlling the delivery of real-time multimedia content, often used in applications like IP cameras?
Variations in packet delay during multimedia transmission, which can affect the smoothness of playback, are referred to as:
Which transmission method is most suitable for live streaming to a large audience due to its one-to-many transmission capability?
Which multimedia streaming approach involves users sharing and distributing content among themselves, reducing the load on central servers?
The number of pixels in an image, defining its level of detail, is referred to as its:
Which color model is commonly used in video compression due to its representation of colors as luma and chroma components?
The ratio of the width to the height of a video frame is known as its: Competing Technologies: Wi-Fi, WiMAX, and FttX
Which of the following wireless technologies is based on the IEEE 802.11 standards?
In Wi-Fi architecture, a group of stations that communicate with each other through a single access point is called a:
Which Wi-Fi security protocol is considered the most secure, offering enhanced security features like stronger encryption and improved key management?
WiMAX technology is based on which IEEE standard?
Which FttX architecture deploys optical fiber to a street cabinet or curb, with the connection extended to homes using existing copper infrastructure?
What is the primary advantage of FttX technologies over traditional copper-based technologies?
Which of the following statements about Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax) is FALSE?
It operates in both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands
It offers higher efficiency and lower latency compared to previous Wi-Fi standards
It is backward compatible with older Wi-Fi devices
It has a maximum theoretical speed of 9.6 Gbps
Which WiMAX standard is primarily designed for providing fixed broadband wireless access?
What is the unique identifier for a Wi-Fi network, allowing devices to distinguish between different networks?
The group of broadband network architectures that use optical fiber to deliver high-speed internet access to end users is referred to as: Emerging techniques: MANET and Cognitive Radio
Which routing protocol is an example of a reactive routing protocol used in MANETs?
The Zone Routing Protocol (ZRP) is classified as a:
The concept of allowing cognitive radios to dynamically access and use available spectrum bands without causing harmful interference to licensed users is known as:
Which potential benefit of cognitive radio is particularly crucial for emergency services and disaster response teams?
In MANETs, nodes act as both:
Which technology enables intelligent and dynamic spectrum management by allowing devices to sense their environment and utilize unused spectrum bands opportunistically?
The ability of a MANET to efficiently handle a large number of nodes while maintaining effective communication and routing is a challenge associated with:
The integration of cognitive radio capabilities into 5G and beyond networks is expected to:
Increase the complexity of network management
Enhance the capacity and efficiency of these networks
Limit the number of devices that can connect to the network
Which security threat is particularly relevant to MANETs due to their dynamic and open nature?
In the context of MANET routing protocols, which category proactively maintains up-to-date routing information by periodically exchanging routing tables?
